subSubSection.paragraph: General distribution. This taxon is known from Israel , Jordan , Saudi Arabia , and Yemen (Andersen 1995).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. Specimens in the current study match well with
N. bergevini popovi Brown, 1951
for body measurements, pattern, and male genitalia. Females do not agree with those of
N. bergevini orientalis Zettel, 1996
, described from Iraq . The easternmost species
N. signatus Distant, 1910
, recorded from India to Vietnam , also exhibits features distinct from specimens collected here (see e.g., Distant 1910b ; Polhemus & Polhemus 1994 , 2000 ; Thirumalai 2002 ;
Chandra et al. 2012
).

The status of the genus and, especially of the subspecies of
N. bergevini Bergroth, 1911
as currently interpreted (see Polhemus & Polhemus 1994 ), is far from satisfactory and needs a taxonomic revision. In particular, in part because of the records reported here, the subspecific status of
N. bergevini popovi
is difficult to justify since another subspecies (
N. bergevini orientalis
from Iraq ) lies interposed between the populations of
N. bergevini popovi
from the Near East (see Andersen 1995) and those from Pakistan . No records of this genus exist for Iran (see Ghahari 2013,
Ghahari et al. 2013
). The taxon was originally described as
Naboandelus popovi
by Brown (1951: 227) and subsequently downgraded to a subspecies of
N. bergevini
by Linnavuori (1975: 46) . However, this taxon should probably be synonymized under
N. bergevini
or deserve specific level status.
